title: Coronavirus Genome
alt: Spellcheck has been great, but whoever figures out how to get grammar check to work is guaranteed a Nobel.
transcript:
[Megan sits at a desk, working on a laptop. A genome sequence is displayed on her laptop screen, shown with a jagged line in a text bubble.]
Cueball (off-screen): So that's the coronavirus genome, huh?
Megan: It is!
Laptop: <A long string of unintelligible letters, presumably the genome>[Cueball walks up and stands behind Megan, still working on the laptop.]
Cueball: It's weird that you can just look at it in a text editor.
Megan: It's essential!
Megan: We geneticists do most of our work in Notepad.[A frameless panel, Cueball still standing behind Megan. Megan rests her arm on the chair. ]
Cueball: Notepad?
Megan: Yup! Nicer labs use Word, which lets you change the genome font size and make nucleotides bold or italic.
Cueball: Ah, okay.
Megan: That extra formatting is called "epigenetics".[A regular panel. Cueball still stands behind Megan, this time with his hand on his chin.]
Cueball: Hey, why does that one have a red underline?
Megan: When we identify a virus, we add its genome to spellcheck. That's how we spot mutations.
Cueball: Clever!
